title: eBay blasted for putting lives at risk over faulty carbon monoxide alarms listings
text:

Carbon monoxide alarms that have failed safety tests keep appearing on eBay despite watchdog warnings.

Consumer champion Which? has blasted the auction website for putting lives at risk over its inability to keep on top of the faulty detection devices.

A Which? probe found hundreds of listings for a wide range of carbon monoxide (CO) and combination CO and smoke alarms that they say failed to detect the killer gas.

The seven unbranded CO alarms that flunked the tests were cheapest making them a more attractive buy for consumers.

Some of the alarms tested have failed previous tests but were back on sale, the watchdog said.

Calling it a “scandal” Which? claimed “eBay had known for years” that some of the products were unsafe.

It said 50 of the CO alarms listed were the same type the watchdog had first warned eBay about three years ago.

And it found 34 dodgy smoke alarms it had previously flagged for potentially putting lives at risk were also widely available on the site.

While eBay has now axed 141 suspect devices from its listings, Which? blasted it for failing to keep on top of the problem.

It is calling on eBay to put in a safety net that prevents the faulty alarms from ending up in homes.

The investigation also found popular sites Wish and AliExpress had listings for CO and smoke alarms that had failed Which? safety tests.

But it revealed Amazon had cleaned up its listings and “taken effective steps to address the problem”.

Which? is now urging the other sites to “take the safety of their customers more seriously” and has handed its dossier to the Office for Product Safety & Standards (OPSS).

And it is warning households who have any of the faulty alarms in their homes to stop using them.

Natalie Hitchins, Which? head of home products and services, said: “It’s a scandal that - even after three years of warnings - eBay still can’t manage to get a grip on preventing potentially lethal products from being sold on its site.

“Other online marketplaces are just as bad. These platforms need to wake up and make the safety of their customers the top priority, with a much more rigorous approach to keeping these products out of people’s homes.

“Unsafe products are now flooding online marketplaces. The OPSS must act to ensure these sites are more effectively policed to stem the toxic tide of dodgy goods.”

(Image: ebay)

Ebay said customer safety was paramount and it had removed all the listings highlighted by the Which? investigation.

It said sellers have also been ordered to contact those who bought the alarms to issue refunds.

AliExpress also said customer safety was paramount and it expected sellers to comply with regulations of each nation where it operates.

And Wish said it was working on removing the products from its platform.

Today Electrical Safety First warned households to only buy CO and smoke alarms from reputable retailers.

Its technical director Martyn Allen said: “We continue to call for better regulation of products sold on these sites.

“Consumers should take into account that when purchasing a smoke alarm and any other electric product from an online marketplace they are generally purchasing from a third party seller leaving them vulnerable to being exposed to substandard products.”
description: Consumer champion and watchdog Which? has blasted the online auction website for allowing the dangerous devices to continue to be sold
